document.docAuthor: Valdés, Ángel, Lundsten, Lonny & Wilson, Nerida G.
document.docTitle: Cuthona methana Valdés & Lundsten & Wilson 2018, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Five new deep-sea species of nudibranchs (Gastropoda: Heterobranchia: Cladobranchia) from the Northeast Pacific

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Five new deep-sea species of nudibranchs (Gastropoda: Heterobranchia: Cladobranchia) from the Northeast Pacific

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 15. Photographs of ventral, lateral and dorsal views of the external morphology of preserved specimens of several Aeolidida. A–B. Holotype of
Cuthona methana
sp. nov.
(SIO-BIC M12413), A. Ventral view of the head; B, Lateral view of the anterior portion of the body. C–D. Paratype of
Cuthona methana
sp. nov.
(SIO-BIC M12412), C. Ventral view of the head; D, Lateral view of the anterior portion of the body. E–F. Specimen of
Zeusia herculea (Linnaeus, 1761)
(SIO-BIC M12136), E. Ventral view of the head; F, Dorsal view of the head. G–H. Holotype of
Aeolidia libitinaria
sp. nov.
(SIO-BIC M12138), G. Ventral view of the head; H, Dorsal view of the head. Abbreviations: a, anus; ot, oral tentacle; pe, penis; rh, rhinophores; ro, reproductive opening.

FIGURE 16. Drawings of the internal anatomy of the paratype of
Cuthona methana
sp. nov.
(SIO-BIC M12412). A. General view of the internal anatomy. B. Reproductive system. Abbreviations: am, ampulla; bb, buccal bulb; bc, bursa copulatrix; cns, central nervous system; dg, digestive gland; es, esophagus; fgc, female gland complex; i, intestine; pe, penis.

FIGURE 17. SEMs of the radula and jaws of the paratype of
Cuthona methana
sp. nov.
(SIO-BIC M12412). A. Radular teeth. B. Lateral view of a radular tooth. C. Jaw. D. Jaw masticatory border.

subSubSection.paragraph: Biology. This species was collected at 587 m depth on Hydrate Ridge, an area of methane seeps about 44 nautical miles off Newport , Oregon ( Fig. 1 ). Both animals were collected off inactive rocks around seep areas. The holotype was collected from E7 sterile rock 8 and the paratype from E7 large rock 20a (Levin lab experiments).
Etymology. This species is named for the methane seep environment where it was found.

Remarks. Molecular data could not be generated for
Cuthona methana
, but this species is morphologically different from all other species of
Cuthona
described from the Eastern Pacific.

Cella et al. (2016)
proposed a new taxonomy for species previously assigned to
Cuthona
including the resurrection of
Tenellia
A. Costa, 1866 and the introduction of several new genera. Although this classification scheme is not as complex as that by Korshunova et al. (2017), it also based on poorly resolved trees and makes the placement of species not studied genetically, such as
Cuthona methana
sp. nov.
, more difficult. The phylogenetic relationships of aeolids are in a state of flux due to lack of resolution for lower branches, and only next generation sequencing techniques appear to provide resolution for critical nodes (
Goodheart et al. 2017
). Because it is virtually impossible for us to determine the phylogenetic position of
Cuthona methana
sp. nov.
in
Cuthona
,
Tenellia
, or any of the new genera described by
Cella et al. (2016)
, it is here conservatively regarded as a member of
Cuthona .

Among the known Eastern Pacific species,
Cuthona methana
sp. nov.
is only externally similar to
C. divae (Ev. Marcus, 1961)
, but lacks the brown to pink pigment digestive branches in the cerata and the rhinophores are pinkish, instead of translucent white ( Behrens & Hermosillo 2005 ). Internally, the radula of
C. divae
(described by MacFarland, 1966 —under the name
Cuthona rosea MacFarland, 1966
) has a triangular rachidian tooth with numerous lateral denticles, very different from that of
C. methana
, which has a much narrower rachidian tooth with only 3 denticles on each side of the cusp.
